The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned alot about how the constitution was made.
This course was an in-depth examination of the American political system as well as a view of  how our political system could have unfolded differently.
How to think critically about historical documents and relate them to present day
I learned a lot about the American Constitutional convention and what failed proposals never made it through. I also learned how to analyze and dissect older texts
A greater understanding of the Federal Convention of 1789 and the founding of America.

Learned about the constitution and America's beginning. Really interesting to learn the thoughts of the founding fathers and how they created the constitution. ALso interesting to hear the opposing beliefs

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Fairdosi was super engaging and conversations were amazing. the readings were a lot.
The reading responses, class discussions in seminar and highly focussed research paper gave multiple opportunities for mastery of the material.
The class topic was very interesting but, sometimes it felt a bit unorganized.

Strengths: Professor Fairdosi is very knowledgeable about the material and selects great readings to facilitate discussion:

Weaknesses: sometimes its clear people lack engagement with the class and the same students need to facilitate discussion for everyone else.

Strengths: Professor Fairdosi allows you to gain what you put into the course without putting unnecessary stress or pressure on you. This allowed me to enjoy the readings and assignments because I did not feel stressed. The questions we talked about were also interesting and the concept of the course seemed novel. Also, the introductory lectures were also very good!

Improvements: This is the first time the course was taught so a few improvements could help. A lot of the required readings were from the records of the Federal Convention but then the vast majority of the conversation was about present day issues. As a result, the pages to read from the federal convention should be more targeted so that students read what is relevant and then more current readings can be introduced.
Was a little bit boring but cant do much about that because it is about the "Start" of America

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in the Constitution, YES!
I would definitely recommend this course. Not only did we learn a tremendous amount, the envirnoment cerated by Professor Fairdosi was comfortable and encouraged discussion.
I would! It was an interesting discussion every day
Yes! super interesting course material and a great political science professor.
I would if they are interested in the founding of America and want a less pressured environment to learn in then yes.
Absolutely. Great to learn about the foundation of America and its beginnings.

I think any course with Professor Fairdosi is a good one. Like every seminar, I think what makes or breaks this class is the composition of students and willingness to participate. Occasionally there were some really interesting conversations, other times it fell flat. Professor Fairdosi did a good job of trying to stimulate conversation, and I think that topic, content, and structure of the class has wonderful potential if it continues in the future!
